{{Year nav topic5|1522|literature}} This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1522'''.
==Events== *[[September 21]] – [[Luther Bible]]: [[Martin Luther]]'s [[Bible translations|translation]] of the [[Bible]]'s [[New Testament]] into [[Early New High German]] from Greek, ''Das newe Testament Deutzsch'', is published in Germany, selling thousands in the first few weeks. *[[Luo Guanzhong]]'s 14th-century compilation ''[[Romance of the Three Kingdoms]]'' is first printed, as ''Sanguozhi Tongsu Yanyi''.
==New books== [[File:Gutenberg Bible.jpg|thumb|3rd ''[[Textus Receptus]]'']] <!-- (''Title of published book translation''), ("Title of published poem/story translation"), (Literal translation of title) --> ===Prose=== *[[Desiderius Erasmus]] – ''Novum Testamentum'' (Greek ''[[Textus Receptus]]'' of the [[New Testament]], third edition) *[[Martin Luther]] – ''[[Against Henry, King of the English]]'' (''Contra Henricum Regem Anglie'') *[[Adam Ries]] – ''{{lang|de|Rechenung auff der Linihen und Federn}}''
===Drama=== *[[Niklaus Manuel Deutsch I]] – ''Vom Papst und Christi Gegensatz'' *''[[The World and the Child]]'' (''Mundus et Infans'', published)
===Poetry=== {{main|1522 in poetry}} *[[Thomas Murner]] – ''Von dem grossen Lutherischen Narren'' ("Of the Great Lutheran Fool")<ref>{{cite book|last=Thomas|first=Calvin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n9EPAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22German+literature%22&as_brr=3&ei=NqwmS-W3BKT8ygSx-emvCw&cd=3#v=onepage&q=&f=false|title=A History of German Literature|location=New York|publisher=D. Appleton & Co|year=1909|accessdate=2009-12-14}}</ref> *''Approximate years'' **[[Biernat of Lublin]] – ''Zywot Ezopa'' ("The Life of Aesop")<ref>{{cite book|author1=Preminger, Alex |author2=Brogan, T. V. F. |title=The New Princeton Encyclopedia of Poetry and Poetics|year=1993|location=New York|publisher=MJF Books/Fine Communications|display-authors=etal}}</ref> **[[Robert Copland]] – ''[[Ipomadon]]'' (derived from the Anglo-Norman ''Ipomedon'' (c. 1190) of [[Hue de Rotelande]])<ref>{{cite book|editor=Cox, Michael|title=The Concise Oxford Chronology of English Literature|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|isbn=0-19-860634-6}}</ref>
==Births== *[[June 1]] – [[Dirck Volckertszoon Coornhert]], Dutch classical scholar (died [[1590 in literature|1590]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Joachim du Bellay]], French poet (died [[1560 in literature|1560]]) **[[Louise Labé]], French poet (died [[1566 in literature|1566]]) **[[Siôn Tudur]], Welsh poet (died [[1602 in literature|1602]])
==Deaths== *[[February 25]] – [[William Lilye]], English classical scholar (born c. [[1468 in literature|1468]]) *[[June 30]] – [[Johann Reuchlin]], German humanist scholar and poet (born [[1455 in literature|1455]]) *September – [[Gavin Douglas]], Scottish poet and bishop (born c. [[1474 in literature|1474]])

{{unreferenced|date=February 2013}} {{Year nav topic5|1623|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1623'''.
==Events== *[[February 2]] ([[Candlemas]]) – The [[King's Men (playing company)|King's Men]] perform ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' at the court of King [[James I of England]]. <!--also shown under 1622 – which is correct? *[[February 28]] – John Hacket's Latin comedy ''Loiola'' is staged at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] (and is repeated on [[March 12]] for King [[James I of England|James]] on his third visit to the University. The play mocks both [[Roman Catholicism|Catholics]], in the person of [[Ignatius Loyola]], and [[Calvinism|Calvinists]], who are represented by Martinus, a canting elder of [[Amsterdam]].--> *[[June 29]] – [[Pedro Calderón de la Barca]] makes his debut as a playwright, his ''{{lang|es|Amor, honor y poder}}'' (''Love, Honor and Power'') being performed at the Spanish Court. Two other plays follow this year. *[[July 20]] – [[Henry Herbert (Master of the Revels)|Henry Herbert]] (Sir Henry from August) becomes deputy to Sir John Ashley, [[Master of the Revels]] and takes over his duties. Herbert effectively control professonal drama in England from 1623 until the theaters close in 1642. *Between [[November 8]] and early December – Publication of the "[[First Folio]]" (''Mr. William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies''), a collection of 36 of the plays of [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]], half of which have not previously been printed, compiled posthumously by actors [[John Heminges]] and [[Henry Condell]] and published by Isaac Jaggard and [[Edward Blount]] in London. *[[Procopius]]'s long-lost ''Secret History'' is rediscovered in the Vatican Library. *[[François le Métel de Boisrobert]] comes under the patronage of [[Cardinal Richelieu]]. [[Image:First Folio.jpg|thumb|right|The [[First Folio]]]]
==New books== *[[Francis Bacon]] – ''{{lang|la|De Augmentis Scientiarum}}'' *[[Jakob Böhme]] **''On Election to Grace'' **''On Christ's Testaments'' **''{{lang|la|Mysterium Magnum}}'' **''Clavis (Key)'' *[[Tommaso Campanella]] – ''{{lang|la|Civitas Solis}} ("[[The City of the Sun]]")'' *[[William Drummond of Hawthornden]] – ''Flowers of Sion'' *[[James Mabbe]] – ''[[Guzmán de Alfarache]]'', translated from the Spanish original by [[Mateo Alemán]] *[[Giambattista Marini]] – ''Adone'' *[[Antonio de León Pinelo]] – ''{{lang|es|Discurso de la importancia, de la forma, y de la disposicion de la colleccion de las leyes de Indias}}'' *[[George Wither]] – ''Hymnes and Songs of the Church''
==New drama== *Anonymous (Robert Ward?) – ''Fucus Histriomastix'' *[[Richard Brome]] – ''A Fault in Friendship'' (lost), his earliest known play *[[Pedro Calderón de la Barca]] **''{{lang|es|Amor, honor y poder}}'' **''{{lang|es|La selva confusa}}'' **''{{lang|es|Los Macabeos}}'' *[[Thomas Dekker (poet)|Thomas Dekker]] (& [[John Day (dramatist)|John Day]]?) – ''The Wonder of a Kingdom'' *Thomas Dekker, [[John Ford (dramatist)|John Ford]], & [[William Rowley]] (?) – ''[[The Spanish Gypsy]]'' *[[Thomas Drue]] – ''The Duchess of Suffolk'' *[[John Fletcher (playwright)|John Fletcher]] and [[Philip Massinger]] – ''[[The Lovers' Progress]]'' *John Fletcher and [[William Rowley]] – ''[[The Maid in the Mill]]'' *John Hacket – ''Loiola'' *[[Ben Jonson]] – ''[[Time Vindicated to Himself and to His Honours]]'' ([[masque]]) *[[Philip Massinger]] **''[[The Bondman]]'' (performed) **''[[The Duke of Milan]]'' (published) *Robert Ward (?) – ''Fucus Histriomastix'' *[[John Webster]] **''[[The Duchess of Malfi]]'' (published) **''[[The Devil's Law Case]]'' (published)
==Poetry== {{Main|1623 in poetry}} *[[Martin Opitz]] – ''{{lang|de|Lob des Feldlebens}}''
==Births== *[[June 19]] – [[Blaise Pascal]], French philosopher (died [[1662 in literature|1662]]) *[[October 17]] – [[Francis Turretin]], Swiss theologian (died [[1687 in literature|1687]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Margaret Cavendish]], Duchess of Newcastle, English biographer, poet and philosopher (died [[1673 in literature|1673]]) **[[Francesco Negri (travel writer)|Francesco Negri]], Italian priest and travel writer (died [[1698 in literature|1698]]) **[[Henri Sauval]], French historian (died [[1676 in literature|1676]])
==Deaths== *[[January 15]] – [[Paolo Sarpi]], Venetian church historian (born [[1552 in literature|1552]]) *July/August – [[Tulsidas]], Hindu philosopher and poet (born [[1532 in literature|1532]]) *November – [[William Jaggard]], English printer (born c. 1568) *[[November 9]] – [[William Camden]], English historian (born [[1551 in literature|1551]]) *[[November 11]] – [[Philippe de Mornay]], French Protestant writer (born [[1549 in literature|1549]]) *[[December 31]] – [[Philipp Clüver]], German historian (born [[1580 in literature|1580]])

{{refimprove|date=November 2013}} {{Year nav topic5|1744|literature|poetry}}
This article presents a list of the literary events and publications in '''1744'''.
==Events== *[[February 5]] – [[Spranger Barry]] makes his debut as an actor at the [[Theatre Royal, Dublin]]. *[[February 6]] – [[Samuel Foote]] makes his debut as an actor as [[Othello (character)|Othello]] at the [[Haymarket Theatre]], [[London]]. *April – ''The Female Spectator'' (a monthly) is founded by [[Eliza Haywood]] in England, the first periodical written for women by a woman. *[[April 14]] – The Physico-Historical Society is formed in Dublin for the preservation of 'manuscripts, rare printed books, and natural curiosities relating to Ireland'.<ref>{{cite book|editor=Moody, T. W.|title=A New History of Ireland. '''8''': A Chronology of Irish History|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1989|isbn=978-0-19-821744-2|display-editors=etal}}</ref> *[[May 29]] – [[Alexander Pope]] is received into the [[Catholic Church]], a day before his death.
==New books== ===Fiction=== *[[Mary Collyer]] – ''Felicia to Charlotte'' *[[Sarah Fielding]] – ''The Adventures of David Simple'' *[[Eliza Haywood]] – ''The Fortunate Foundlings'' *[[Edward Moore (dramatist)|Edward Moore]] – ''Fables for the Female Sex'' *[[William Oldys]] – ''[[The Harleian Miscellany]]'' (introduction by Samuel Johnson) *[[Joseph Warton]] – ''The Enthusiast''
===Children=== *[[John Newbery]] – ''[[A Little Pretty Pocket-Book]]'' *''[[Tommy Thumb's Pretty Song Book]]'' (earliest extant English nursery-rhyme collection)
===Drama=== *[[Robert Dodsley]] – ''A Select Collection of Old Plays'' *William Harvard – ''Regulus'' *[[James Miller (playwright)|James Miller]] **''Joseph and his Brethren'' (music by [[Handel]]) **''Mahomet the Imposter'' (adapted from [[Voltaire]]'s ''[[Mahomet (play)|Mahomet]]''; completed by [[John Hoadly (playwright)|John Hoadly]]) *Thomas Odell – ''The Prodigal'' *James Ralph – ''The Astrologer'' (adapted from [[Thomas Tomkis]]'s ''Albumazar'', itself adapted from [[Giambattista della Porta]]'s ''L'astrologo'') *[[Antonio de Zamora]] – ''No hay deuda que no se pague y convidado de piedra''
===Poetry=== *[[Mark Akenside]] **''[[The Pleasures of the Imagination]]'' **''An Epistle to Curio'' *[[Jane Brereton]] – ''Poems'' *[[Gabriel Álvarez de Toledo]] (ed. [[Diego de Torres Villarroel]]) – ''Obras póstumas poéticas, con la Burromaquia''
===Non-fiction=== *[[John Armstrong (poet)|John Armstrong]] – ''The Art of Preserving Health'' *[[George Berkeley]] – ''Siris'' *[[Émilie du Châtelet|Émilie de Breteuil, marquise du Chatelet]] -''Dissertation sur la nature et la propagation du feu'' *[[Colley Cibber]] – ''Another Occasional Letter from Mr. Cibber to Mr. [[Alexander Pope|Pope]]'' *[[David Garrick]] – ''An Essay on Acting'' (attrib.) *[[Samuel Johnson]] **''[[Life of Mr Richard Savage]]'' **''An Account of the Life of John Philip Barretier'' *[[Alexander Pope]] – ''[[Essay on Man]]'', volume 4: "[[Epistle]]: Of the Nature and State of Man, with Respect to" (4) "Happiness" (the first 2 epistles were written in 1732 and the third in 1733). *[[John Ranby]] – ''The Method of Treating Gunshot Wounds'' *[[Emanuel Swedenborg]] – ''The Animal Kingdom'' (Soul's Domain) (1744–45) *[[Jonathan Swift]] – ''Three Sermons''
==Births== *[[January 29]] – [[Catharina Charlotta Swedenmarck]], Swedish writer (died [[1813 in literature|1813]]) *[[February 10]] – [[William Mitford]], English historian (died [[1827 in literature|1827]]) *[[April 11]] (baptised) – [[Elizabeth Bonhôte]], English novelist, essayist and poet (died [[1818 in literature|1818]]) *[[August 25]] – [[Johann Gottfried Herder]], German poet (died [[1803 in literature|1803]]) *December – [[Elsa Fougt]], Swedish editor and publisher (died [[1826 in literature|1826]])
==Deaths== *[[January 28]] – [[Thomas Innes (historian)|Thomas Innes]], Scottish historian (born [[1662 in literature|1662]]) *[[March 31]] – [[Antiochus Kantemir]], Russian diplomat and writer (born [[1708 in literature|1708]]) *[[April 27]] – [[James Miller (playwright)|James Miller]], English playwright, poet and satirist (born [[1704 in literature|1704]]) *[[May 30]] – [[Alexander Pope]], English poet and satirist (born [[1688 in literature|1688]]) *[[September 18]] – [[Lewis Theobald]], English literary historian (born [[1688 in literature|1688]])

{{Year nav topic5|1960|film|television|radio }} {{Yearsinfilm}} <!-- SIDEBAR NAV-BOX --> The year '''1960 in film''' involved some significant events. __TOC__
==Events== * March 5 - For the first time since coming home from military service in Germany, [[Elvis Presley]] returns to [[Hollywood]] to film ''[[G.I. Blues]]'' * June 16 - Premiere of [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s landmark film, [[Psycho (1960 film)|Psycho]]. Controversial since release, it set new standards in violence and sexuality on screen, and was a critical influence on the emerging [[Slasher film|slasher]] genre. * August 10 - Filming of ''[[West Side Story (film)|West Side Story]]'' begins. * October 27 - Film ''[[Saturday Night and Sunday Morning (film)|Saturday Night and Sunday Morning]]'' released, first of the British [[Social realism|social-realist]] wave. * November 4 - Filming wraps on ''[[The Misfits (film)|The Misfits]]'', starring [[Marilyn Monroe]] and [[Clark Gable]] (the last film for both, though Monroe was working on another at the time of her death).

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} An '''advance reading copy''', '''advance review copy''', '''advance reader's edition''', '''advance copy''', or a '''reader's edition''' ('''ARC''' or '''ARE''') is a free copy of a new [[book]] given by a publisher to booksellers, librarians, journalists, celebrities, or others, or as a contest or school prize,<ref name="ltblog">{{cite web|url=http://www.librarything.com/blogs/librarything/2007/05/page/2/|title=Archive for May, 2007|work=The Librarything Blog|accessdate=25 February 2012|author=Tim|date=May 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070519130920/http://www.librarything.com/blog/2007_05_01_archive.php|archivedate=May 19, 2007}}</ref> before the book is printed for mass distribution.
==Overview== ARCs may lack the final [[dust jacket]], formatting, and binding of the finished product. The text of an advance edition may also differ slightly from the market book (the final version that is distributed for sale), because changes may be made after advance readers make comments or find errors in the manuscript. When a celebrity reader or journalist gives an endorsement, that may be added to the dust-cover and other promotional items.
ARCs are normally distributed three to six months before the book is officially released to reviewers, bookstores, magazines, and (in some cases) libraries.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}
Book collectors often seek ARCs, which may contain text errors or typos that add value, as coins or stamps with errors do.
On rare occasions (for instance, on the publication of an eagerly awaited or controversial book), a publisher may require the recipients of an ARC to sign a [[Confidentiality agreement|confidentiality of content agreement]]. However, in most cases the sheer number of ARCs produced and distributed makes that impractical. A typical genre publisher will produce 5,000 ARCs for a new book by a moderately popular writer.<ref name="ltblog"/>
Before it was a common practice to produce and distribute ARCs in this way, publishers used uncorrected, bound [[galley proof]]s only for the editing and proof-reading process. Typically, they were bound in plain paper covers without illustrations, printed in black and white, and significantly larger than their market book counterparts. In contrast, ARCs usually are printed in full color, and have bindings, format, and illustrations that are similar to those of the market book. The phrase 'uncorrected proof' appears on the ARC cover.
Although ARCs are usually free promotional items, some early versions of books, even some labeled by the publisher as ARCs, are sold to the public. An example is ''[[Captain Vorpatril's Alliance]]'' by [[Lois McMaster Bujold]].
==Digital advance copies==
Publishers who produce galley proofs in electronic form rather than as a physical book do not use them as ARCs. However, with the rise of ebooks and ereaders, it is now common for ARCs (in contrast to galley proofs) to be distributed as [[EBook|eBooks]] on websites such as NetGalley. Both traditionally published and self-published ARCs may be available for distribution on such sites. Recently, '''eARC''' has come into common use for advance copies of eBooks.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lili|title=The In’s and Out’s of NetGalley|url=http://blog.netgalley.com/guest-post-the-ins-and-outs-of-netgalley/|website=NetGalley|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref> This usage dates back to at least 2010<ref>{{cite web|title=eBooks and Advanced Reading Copies (eARCs)|url=https://bitethebook.com/2010/11/10/ebooks-and-advanced-reading-copies-earcs/|website=Bite The Book|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref> and was promoted by [[Baen Books]] for their trade eBooks from at least 2013 onward.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ebooks beta|url=https://ebooks.stackexchange.com/questions/235/are-baen-earc-editions-generally-very-different-from-final-published-books|website=Stack Exchange|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref>

(English: "Immortal soldier") | embedded = | findagrave = | source = [http://www.indiagate.org.in/amar-jawan-jyoti.htm Official webpage] }} '''Amar Jawan Jyoti''' ({{lang-hi|अमर जवान ज्योति}}) (English translation: ''Flame of the immortal soldier'') is an Indian [[memorial]] constructed after the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971]] to commemorate the martyred and unknown soldiers of the [[Indian Armed Forces]] who died during the war. The memorial was constructed in December 1971 and inaugurated by [[Indira Gandhi]] in 1972. Amar Jawan Jyoti is located under [[India Gate]] at [[Rajpath]] in [[New Delhi]] and consists of a marble pedestal on which a [[cenotaph]] is situated. "Amar Jawan" (Immortal Soldier) is scripted in gold on all four sides of the cenotaph and on top, a [[L1A1 self-loading rifle]] stands on its barrel with a helmet of the Unknown Soldier on top. The pedestal is bound by four urns, one of which holds a continuously burning flame. [[File:CNS Admiral RK Dhowan lays a wreath at Amar Jawan Jyoti-2.jpg|thumb|cenotaph with a [[L1A1 self-loading rifle]] placed on its barrel and capped by a helmet of the Unknown Soldier.]] ==History== From 3 December 1971 to 16 December 1971 ([[Fall of Dhaka]]), India had a military confrontation with [[Pakistan]] ([[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971]]) during the [[Bangladesh Liberation War|liberation war]] in [[East Pakistan]].{{cite news|title=India-Pakistan 1971 war|work=[[The Indian Express]]|accessdate=4 January 2017|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/explained/india-pakistan-1971-war-bangladesh-indira-gandhi-4429236/}} [[Creation of Bangladesh]] was assisted by India during which many Indian soldiers lost their lives.{{cite news|title=Amar Jyoti|publisher=discoveredindia.com|accessdate=4 January 2017|url=http://www.discoveredindia.com/delhi/attractions/samadhis/amar-jyoti.htm}} In December 1971, after the ''Indo-Pakistani War of 1971'', [[Indira Gandhi]] (then [[Prime Minister of India]]) helped pay to construct the ''Amar Jawan Jyoti'' under the [[India Gate]] to commemorate the dead and unknown soldiers who died invading Pakistan. On 26 January 1972 (23rd Republic Day of India), the monument was officially inaugurated by Indira Gandhi.{{cite news|title=Amar Jawan Jyoti|publisher=indiagate.org.in|accessdate=4 January 2017|url=http://www.indiagate.org.in/amar-jawan-jyoti.htm}} Since 1972, every-year on the [[Republic Day (India)|Republic Day]] (before the [[Delhi Republic Day parade|Republic Day parade]]), it has been customary for the [[President of India|President]], [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister]], [[Chief of the Air Staff (India)|Chief of the Air Staff]], [[Chief of the Naval Staff (India)|Chief of the Naval Staff]], [[Chief of the Army Staff (India)|Chief of the Army Staff]] and dignitaries to place [[wreath]] at ''Amar Jawan Jyoti'' and pay homage to the dead and unknown soldiers.{{cite news|title=Significance of Amar Jawan Jyoti|publisher=indiagate.org.in|accessdate=4 January 2017|url=http://www.indiagate.org.in/articles/significance-of-amar-jawan-jyoti.htm}}{{cite news|title=History|publisher=indiagate.org.in|accessdate=4 January 2017|url=http://www.indiagate.org.in/history.htm}} The main structure (India Gate) was originally constructed in 1921 by [[Edwin Lutyens]]. Amar Jawan Jyoti was added under the India Gate in 1971.{{cite news|title=The India Gate|publisher=thedivineindia.com|accessdate=4 January 2017|url=http://www.thedivineindia.com/the-india-gate/5784}} ==Construction and structure== [[File:Soldier guarding Amar Jawan Jyoti.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[Indian Army]] soldier guarding ''Amar Jawan Jyoti''.]] Amar Jawan Jyoti is located under [[India Gate]] at [[Rajpath]] in [[New Delhi]]. It consists of a marble pedestal on which a [[cenotaph]] is situated. "Amar Jawan" (Immortal Soldier) is scripted in gold on all four sides of the cenotaph and on top, a [[L1A1 self-loading rifle]] is placed on its barrel and is capped by a helmet of the Unknown Soldier. The pedestal is bound by four urns, in one of which a flame has been burning continuously (using [[Compressed natural gas|CNG]]) since 1971. The person responsible for keeping the flame burning lives in a room under the [[India Gate|arch]], next to the perpetually burning flame.{{cite news|title=Keeper of the flame|work=[[The Indian Express]]|accessdate=4 January 2017|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/keeper-of-the-flame/960016/0}} From 1971 to 2006, [[Liquefied petroleum gas|LPG]] was used as fuel source and from 2006, [[Compressed natural gas|CNG]] is used as source. Each of the four urns has a flame but only one of the four flames burns throughout the year; on [[Independence Day (India)|Indian Independence]] and [[Republic Day (India)|Republic Day]]s, all flames are lit simultaneously.{{cite news|title=5 things about Amar Jawan Jyoti|publisher=thebetterindia.com|accessdate=4 January 2017|url=http://www.thebetterindia.com/43484/amar-jawan-jyoti-republic-day-delhi/}} The ''Amar Jawan Jyoti'' is manned [[24/7 service|24/7]] by soldiers from the [[Indian Army|Army]], [[Indian Air Force|Air Force]] and the [[Indian Navy]]. ==Significance== Constructed after the Indo-Pakistani War of 1971, the ''Amar Jawan Jyoti'' commemorates the dead and unknown soldiers who lost their lives in the conflict, that resulted in the creation of independent Bangladesh The burning flame is considered immortal. ==See also== {{commonscat|Amar Jawan Jyoti (Tomb of the Unknown Soldier)}} *[[India Gate]] {{Portal bar|India|Delhi|Military of India}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Delhi}} [[Category:Cultural infrastructure completed in 1971]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in New Delhi]] [[Category:Commonwealth War Graves Commission memorials]] [[Category:Indian military memorials and cemeteries]] [[Category:Military of India]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Delhi]] [[Category:Terminating vistas]] [[Category:Tombs of Unknown Soldiers]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Delhi]] [[Category:Works of Edwin Lutyens in India]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Arts in ''Second Life''}} '''Arts in ''Second Life''''' is an artistic area of a 3D social network (called ''[[Second Life]]'') that has served, since 2003, as a platform for various artistic pursuits and exhibitions. SL Photography is one of the most popular forms of artistic expression with images known as "snapshots" produced while travelling through ''Second Life''{{'}}s virtual environment. Many of these snapshots are displayed through various mediums that include Art Galleries, [[Machinima]] websites and Second Life Magazines. == Art exhibits == Second Life has created an environment where artists can display their works to an audience across the world. This has created an entire artistic culture where many residents display art in the museums, galleries and homes they can buy or build using Second Life's powerful tools. Gallery openings even allow art patrons to "meet" and socialize with exhibiting artists and has even led to many real life sales. Numerous art gallery simulations (called "sims") abound in Second Life. Among the more popular galleries are the Sisse Singhs Art Gallery, the Windlight art Gallery and the Horus Art Gallery. Among the most notable of these was the art gallery sim Cetus Gallery District, the world's first virtual online urban arts district. Cetus was modeled on real world analogs such as New York's Chelsea gallery district as a mixed-use arts community of virtual galleries, offices, loft apartments, and coffee houses. Its many tenant-run businesses featured weekly live music performances, gallery openings, and literary events such as the virtual book launch for "Coming of Age in Second Life: An Anthropologist Explores the Virtually Human," by Tom Boellstorf (Princeton University Press; 2008). Cetus was chosen Best Cultural Site in Second Life in 2007, and its creator avatar Xander Ruttan (real world arts professional Aaron Collins of California), was among the most influential art world avatars in SL. Cetus resulted in many ongoing collaborative efforts among the SL community of artists, designers, writers, and virtual builders from across the real and virtual worlds. (Cetus was later bought by virtual artist DB Bailey and converted into a personal art project). The modeling tools from ''Second Life'' allow the artists also to create new forms of art that in many ways are not possible in real life due to physical constraints or high associated costs. The virtual arts are visible in over 2050 "museums" (according to SL's own search engine).{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/sundayarts/thursdays/ |title=Thursdays |accessdate = 2007-08-15}} In 2008 Haydn Shaughnessy, [[real life]] gallerist, along with his wife Roos Demol hired a [[real life]] architect, [[New York City|New York]] based, Benn Dunkley to design a gallery in Second Life. Dunkleys goal was to design an interactive gallery with art in mind in a virtual world. "Ten Cubed" is a radical departure in art exhibition, a futuristically designed gallery showcasing art in a unique setting. On January 31, 2008, "Ten Cubed" was launched. For its [[inaugural]] exhibition, ''Crossing the Void II'', owner and curator Shaughnessy selected five artists working in and with modern technologies. These artists included Chris Ashley based in [[Oakland, California]], [[Jon Coffelt]] based in [[New York, New York]], Claire Keating based in [[Cork (city)|Cork, Ireland]], Scott Kildall based in [[San Francisco, California]] and [[Nathaniel Stern]] originally based in [[New York, New York]] now in [[Dublin, Ireland]].[http://www.depoconsulting.com/blog/?p=16 Inaugural artists in ''Crossing the Void II''for "Ten Cubed," curated by Haydn Shaughnessy] [[Real life]] as well as Second Life editions are available from the gallery. The virtual creations from the [[metaverse]] are disclosed in real life by initiatives such as Fabjectory (statuettes){{cite web |url=http://www.fabjectory.com/secondlife/ |title=Fabjectory |accessdate = 2007-05-06}} and Secondlife-Art.com (oil paintings).{{cite web| url= http://www.secondlife-art.com/| title= Secondlife-Art.com: real life paintings from Second Life| accessdate= 2007-03-02| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070213084658/http://www.secondlife-art.com/#| archivedate= 2007-02-13| deadurl= yes| df= }} In April 2007 the huge gallery called crossworlds gallery opened its doors in Secondlife; therefore,{{cite web|url=http://www.gallery.de |title=crossworlds gallery at gallery.de |date=2007-04-15 |accessdate=2011-11-18}} the aim was to create an open space for art in virtual worlds. Also in 2007, artists Adam Nash, Christopher Dodds and [[Justin Clemens]] won a A$20,000 Second Life Artists in Residence grant{{cite web|url=http://www.australiacouncil.gov.au/the_arts/features/australias_first_second_life_arts_residency |title=Australia's first Second Life arts residency - Australia Council for the Arts |publisher=Australiacouncil.gov.au |accessdate=2010-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100311224257/http://www.australiacouncil.gov.au/the_arts/features/australias_first_second_life_arts_residency |archivedate=2010-03-11 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/technology/theyre-virtually-famous/2008/04/10/1207856776808.html?s_cid=rss_technology |title=They're virtually famous - Technology |publisher=theage.com.au |date=2009-06-15 |accessdate=2010-02-19}}{{cite web|author=Mahesh Sharma |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/arts/old-funds-for-new-worlds/story-e6frg8n6-1111116470411 |title=Old funds for new worlds |publisher=The Australian |date=2008-05-29 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} from the [[Australia Council for the Arts]]. Their ''Babelswarm'' installation was launched in Second Life and The Lismore Regional Gallery in [[NSW]], Australia on April 11, 2008 by Australia Council Chairman [[James Strong (Australian businessman)|James Strong]].{{cite web |url=http://www.babelswarm.com/review.html |title=Babelswarm |publisher=Babelswarm |date=2008-04-14 |accessdate=2010-02-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707203226/http://www.babelswarm.com/review.html# |archive-date=2011-07-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In 2008, the French Artist Fred Forest{{cite web|url=http://www.webnetmuseum.org/html/en/expo-retr-fredforest/actions/70_a_en.htm#text |title=Web Net Museum-Fred forest-Retrospective-Art sociologique-Esthetique de la communication-Interrogation-Oeuvres Actions-Les robinets planetaires |publisher=Webnetmuseum.org |accessdate=2010-02-19}} had entered the virtual world of Second Life to show his art project for the first time in his country. He inaugurated his "Experimental Center of the Territory of M2" ("Centre expérimental du terrioire du M2"), where he invited politicians to discuss about sustainable development and digital identity card ( Capucine.net). In another art project, he discussed about art institutions in France in his action called "l'art de la corrida". == Live music == Live music performances in ''Second Life'' takes place in three distinctly different ways; * With in-world voice chat, where the user dons a headset and microphone then enables a Second Life browse to "broadcast" his voice to other users, much like a telephone conference call. * With streaming, where vocal and instrumental music by ''Second Life'' residents can be provided with the aid of Internet broadcast software, such as Shoutcast. This is input, via microphones, instruments or other audio sources, into computer audio interfaces and streamed live to audio servers. Similar to webcast radio, the audio stream from the live performance can be received in ''Second Life'' for the enjoyment of other Residents on their computer speakers. This started with performances by Astrin Few in May 2004 and began to gain popularity mid-2005. For example, the UK band Passenger performed on the Menorca Island in mid-2006. Another UK band, [[Redzone]], toured in ''Second Life'' in February 2007. * With inworld samples, where sounds samples are uploaded and an inworld user interface – instruments – is made to trigger those. Unlike streaming, performing with inworld samples make use of the ''Second Life'' environment and creates a three-dimensional sound experience to the audience. The [[Avatar Orchestra Metaverse]] is the most prolific representative with this approach. Linden Lab added an Event Category "Live Music" in March 2006 to accommodate the increasing number of scheduled events. By the beginning of 2008, scheduled live music performance events in ''Second Life'' spanned every musical genre, and included hundreds of live musicians and DJs who perform on a regular basis. A typical day in ''Second Life'' will feature dozens of live music performances. In 2008 the UK act [[Redzone]] announced they would release their new live album only via Second Life.{{cite web|url=http://www.side-line.com/news_comments.php?id=30314_0_2_1_C |title=New Redzone live album only available in Second Life |publisher=Side-line.com |accessdate=2010-02-19}} [[Redzone]] also began choreographing and synchronising their performances via MIDI in October 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.redzone.tv/redzone/press/news/2008.htm |title=MIDI-to-SecondLife Synchronisation Perfected |publisher=Redzone.tv |accessdate=2010-02-19}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Many amateur performers start their music careers in Second Life by performing at virtual karaoke bars{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.ireport.com/docs/DOC-18485 |title=Of Avatars and Microphones |publisher=Ireport.com |date=2008-05-03 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} or Open Mic, then progress to performing for "pay", or Linden dollars, in-world. == Filming with machinima == [[File:Machinima sample reindeer full size.ogg|thumb|right|Film made in Second Life using [[machinima]].]] ''Second Life'' is popular for filming with [[machinima]]. Virtual worlds can contain all aspects of real world filming techniques as well as many more not possible in the real world. It is far easier to create 3D objects in ''Second Life'' and film them than create them from 'scratch' using traditional [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]] software. There are many machinima and performing arts groups that are active in ''Second Life'' and which participate in creative events such as the annual 48 Hour Film Project. There are also several machinima groups that actively promote the works of Second Life artists such as Machinima Mondays, Rezzed TV, MAGE Magazine and the Machinima Artist's guild.{{cite web |url=http://www.48hourfilm.com/en/machinima/|title=The 48 Hour Film Project: Machinima|author=The 48 Hour Film Project|date=January 1, 2014|accessdate=February 3, 2015}} == Theater == Live theater is presented in ''Second Life''. The [[SL Shakespeare Company]]{{cite web|url=http://slshakespeare.com/ |title=The SL Shakespeare Company: Homepage |publisher=Slshakespeare.com |accessdate=2008-10-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081031212730/http://slshakespeare.com/| archivedate= 31 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} performed an act from ''Hamlet'' live in February 2008. In 2009, the company produced scenes from ''[[Twelfth Night]]''. In 2007 Johannes von Matuschka and Daniel Michelis developed Wunderland, an interactive SL theatre play at Schaubühne am Lehniner Platz in Berlin, Germany.{{cite web|url=http://slwunderland.wordpress.com |title=Wunderland |publisher=Slwunderland.wordpress.com |accessdate=2008-10-27}} In 2007, HBO hosted a comedy festival in ''Second Life,''{{cite web |url=http://www.3pointd.com/20070228/hbo-comedy-festival-coming-to-second-life/ |title=HBO Comedy Festival Coming to Second Life |publisher=3pointd.com |date=2007-02-28 |accessdate=2010-02-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707064015/http://www.3pointd.com/20070228/hbo-comedy-festival-coming-to-second-life/# |archive-date=2011-07-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} using live streaming audio. In March 2009, SL residents staged a two-day Virtually Funny Comedy Festival to "help build awareness for Comic Relief, Red Nose Day 2009 and of course, comedy in Second Life."{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.ireport.com/docs/DOC-228896 |title=Virtual Comedians Pick a Red Nose in Second Life |publisher=iReport.com |date=2009-03-13 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} In December 2008, The Learning Experience,{{cite web|url=http://tleinsl.com/index.htm |title=The Learning Experience Web site |publisher=Tleinsl.com |accessdate=2010-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100417125317/http://www.tleinsl.com/index.htm |archivedate=2010-04-17 |df= }} a not-for-profit [[virtual education]] campus in Second Life, staged its first live theater events with the production of two short plays,{{cite web|url=http://tleinsl.blogspot.com/2008/12/it-was-night-of-many-firsts.html |title=It Was a Night of Many Firsts |publisher=Tleinsl.blogspot.com |date=2008-12-05 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} ''A Matter of Husbands'' by [[Ferenc Molnár]] and ''Porcelain and Pink'' by [[F. Scott Fitzgerald]]. In 2009, the TLE theater company began producing full-length plays in Second Life, starting with ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' by [[Oscar Wilde]] in February,{{cite web|url=http://tleinsl.blogspot.com/2009/02/first-full-length-play-staged-by-tle-in.html |title=First Full-length Play Staged by TLE in Virtual World Is a Real Success! |publisher=Tleinsl.blogspot.com |date=2009-02-22 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} and followed by ''Candida'' by [[George Bernard Shaw]] in April.{{cite web|url=http://tleinsl.blogspot.com/2009/04/sexes-battle-it-out-in-candida-on-tle.html |title=The Sexes Battle It Out in Candida on the TLE Stage in Second Life |publisher=Tleinsl.blogspot.com |date=2009-04-03 |accessdate=2010-02-19}}{{cite web|url=http://tleinsl.blogspot.com/2009/04/dont-miss-virtually-real-performance-of.html |title=Don't Miss 'Virtually Real' Performance of Candida at TLE in Second Life |publisher=Tleinsl.blogspot.com |date=2009-04-12 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} In 2008 The [[Avatar Repertory Theater]] company was set up. This is another Theatre company that works within SL."Theatre in the Virtual World- A look at Avatar Repertory Theater" ''Breaking Character''25 September 2012 last accessed 2012-10-24 In 2009 the Department of Drama at the University of Calgary mounted four short productions in the New Media Consortium theater as part of a class in performance in non-traditional spaces. These plays were (a) ''Guppies'' (by Clem Martini) in March (b) [http://www.10-minute-plays.com/comedies/the_chocolate_affair.html The Chocolate Affair] (by Stephanie Alison Walker); (c) [http://www.10-minute-plays.com/comedies/kingdom_of_the_spider.html Kingdom of the Spider] (by Nick Zagone); (d) [http://www.freedrama.net/one.html The Boy Who Cried Genie] (by D. M. Bocaz-Larson).Jim Parker and Clem Martini. Producing Live Theatre in Virtual Spaces: Real Performances/Alternative Landscape , Arts in Society Conference 2010, Sydney Australia, 22–25 July.Jim Parker and Clem Martini, Puppetry of the Pixel: Producing Live Theatre in Virtual Spaces, 3rd IEEE International Workshop on Digital Entertainment, Networked Virtual Environments, and Creative Technology - CCNC 2011: 3rd IEEE International Workshop on Digital Entertainment, Networked Virtual Environments, and Creative Technology, Las Vegas, NV. Jan 9-11, 2011. In 2011/12, an all-[[Furry fandom|furry]] performing arts troupe, Ravenswood Theatricals, was launched at their own venue with successful, non-commercial virtual renditions of [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]]'s ''[[The Wizard of Oz (2011 musical)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' and ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'', the latter of which was received with glowing reviews.Forepawz Golem, "[http://www.slarf.org/phantom-of-the-opera/ The Phantom of the Opera — Show Review]," ''Second Life Avatar Review Files'', March 31, 2012."[http://renoobed.wordpress.com/2011/11/19/the-ravenswood-theatre-company-presents-phantom-of-the-opera/ The Ravenswood Theatre Company Presents Phantom of the Opera]," ''Renoobed'', Nov. 19, 2011. A number of further productions of established real-life pieces such as ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'', ''[[Tanz der Vampire]]'', ''[[Sunset Boulevard (musical)|Sunset Boulevard]]'', and ''[[Into the Woods]]'' are reportedly planned, as well as a gala presentation of various musical numbers from upcoming productions. ==Virtual dance== [[Virtual dance]] has been elevated in Second Life. Ballet Pixelle® (formerly Second Life Ballet) was the first performing [[ballet company]] in Second Life (2006). Ballet Pixelle®, with founder and artistic director Inarra Saarinen, produces all original animations, choreography, and music composed specifically for each ballet. All dance is done as art, not automation, with the dancers actually dancing with each other and the music—there is no artificial synchronization involved.{{Cite web |url=http://wwwballetpixelle.org/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2018-11-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130727204428/http://wwwballetpixelle.org/# |archive-date=2013-07-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }} La Performance.http://www.la-performance.org/ started in May 2008 with live dance shows. Two shows are produced in a year, in March/April/May 2010 modern ballet show 'BACK TO BLACK'http://www.la-performance.org/show/174/back-to-black with music by [[Queen (band)]], [[Francisco de la Torre (composer)|Francisco de la Torre]], [[Metallica]], [[Amy Winehouse]], [[Paula Cole]], [[Richard Wagner]], [[Louis Armstrong]], [[Suzi Quatro]]. October/November/December 2010: 'POLYAMOUR': this modern ballet show was danced live to a live concert by REIS and Aldo Brizzi (vocals and electronics). March/April/May 2011: 'ROMANCE'. November/December 2011/January 2012: 'BORN'. March/April/May 2012: 'INSENSATEZ'. ==Books == There have been several books written about experiences in ''Second Life''. ''Second Life Love''{{ cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/book/second-life-love/id466840476?mt=11 | title=Second Life Love (iTunes)}}{{ cite web |url= https://www.amazon.com/Second-Life-Love-Olsen/dp/1447816242/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1322436821&sr=1-3 | title=Second Life Love (Amazon)}} is example of such a book. It is a dialog between Per Olsen en Li Gang Qin about their partnership in Second Life. The authors have never seen each other in real life.
Other books include ''Second Life For Dummies''{{ cite web |url=https://www.amazon.ca/Second-Life-Dummies-Sarah-Robbins/dp/0470180250 | title=Second Life For Dummies (Amazon)}} by Sarah Robbins and Mark Bell, which was published in 2008 and provides assistance for new users of the virtual world, including basics, how to meet people, ideas for activities and places to visit, including how to access real life education in ''Second Life''. ==Second Life artists== === Annabeth Robinson === {{Main article|Annabeth Robinson}} Annabeth Robinson, or AngryBeth Shortbread, creates online performances or installations using Second Life. For example, Robinson contributed to the 'Kritical Works in SL' project in 2008 to create a sound installation called ''Ping Space''.{{cite journal|last=Doyle |first=Denise |title=Virtual Worlds and New Realms of Creativity: The Kritical Works in SL Project |journal=International Journal of Performance Arts and Digital Media |volume=4 |issue=2-3 |pages=137–153(17) |date=1 May 2008 |url=http://www.tulane.edu/~simon/misc/Mardi%20Gras%20Conference%20Proceedings%202009/Session%202/Doyle.pdf |accessdate=2011-10-25 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} This was a piece of work that involved two cubes reverberating sound from each other which would only happen when one cube was 300 ft above the other. Other such work can be found at the [[Annabeth Robinson]] page. === Garrett Lynch === {{Main article|Garrett Lynch}} Garrett Lynch is an Irish new media artist working with networked technologies in a variety of forms including online art, installation, performance and writing. Since 2008 he has created a series of installation and performance works dealing with ideas of identity and place as they relate to networked spaces. In these works Lynch explores the "real" and the "virtual" through the transposing of his own identity to virtual worlds such as [[Second life|Second Life]] without any attempt to masquerade or imagine a new identity. This process involves the use of his real name for his "representation" or avatar, word play that references his names origins as both real and Irish and the use of a [[sandwich board]] prop stating this that is worn continuously. In 2010/2011 he was artist in residence at [[HUMlab]], Yoshikaze Up-in-the-Air Residency.{{cite web | url=http://yoshikaze.blogspot.co.uk/search/label/Garrett%20Lynch | title=Yoshikaze Up-in-the-Air Residency | author= |work= | publisher=Yoshikaze Up-in-the-Air Residency | accessdate=18 May 2012}}{{cite web | url=http://blog.humlab.umu.se/?p=2739 | title=HUMlab weblog announcing new artist | author=Jim Barrett |date=29 November 2010 |work= | publisher=HUMlab | accessdate=18 May 2012}} Outcomes of the residence have since been published as an artists book and an article in Metaverse Creativity (Volume 2, Number 2).{{cite journal |last=Lynch |first=Garrett |title=A Metaverse Art Residency: ‘Garrett Lynch Yoshikaze "Up-in-the-air" Second Life Residency’ |journal=Metaverse Creativity |volume=2 |issue=2 |year=2012 |pages=163–181 |publisher=Intellect Journals}} Currently Lynch has and is currently performing with a custom-built scale reproduction of his Second Life "representations" sandwich board. This has been worn at a number of exhibitions and performances.{{cite web|url=http://www.dorkbot.org/dorkbotcardiff/meeting03.htm |title=Dorkbot Cardiff #3 |author= |date=14 July 2011 |work= |publisher=Dorkbot Cardiff |accessdate=18 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017083234/http://www.dorkbot.org/dorkbotcardiff/meeting03.htm |archivedate=17 October 2013 }}{{cite web | url=http://decemberlab.wordpress.com/2011/05/29/being-19th-28th-may-2011/ | title=Being | author= |date=19–28 May 2011 |work= | publisher=DecemberLab | accessdate=17 May 2012}} === Gleman Jun === Gleman Jun is an Italian artist in Second Life. In the dynamic effects of colors, lights and transparencies, he expresses his creativity in a constantly evolving and transforming himself. In his case, a work of art is composed of two different elements: vision and technique. "Vision" is the image that passes through his mind suddenly. "Technique" is the experience that allows the memory to translate the vision into a "real" and shareable object. === Second Front === Second Front is the first performance art group of [[Second life|Second Life]]. Founded in 2006, its current seven-member troupe includes Gazira Babeli (Italy), Yael Gilks (London), [[Bibbe Hansen]] (New York), Doug Jarvis (Victoria), [[Scott Kildall]] (San Francisco), Patrick Lichty (Chicago) and Liz Solo (St. Johns). Second Front members collaborate remotely and their performances have been shown live in New York, Los Angeles, Moscow, Brussels, Berlin, Vancouver and many other cities. The group has been written about in publications including [[ArtForum]], [[Art in America]], Realtime Arts (Australia), Exibart (Italy) and Digital Art, (Second Edition) by [[Christiane Paul (curator)]]. ==Second Life Art group== SL Art is one of the most popular art groups in Second Life. Its goal is to recognize the art in virtual worlds at the same level of [[Outline of the visual arts|visual art]] in real life. There are several second Life publications that work to promote Second Life Art, including Windlight Magazine,http://wwwwindlightmagazine.com{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} the SL Newser,http://slnewser.blogspot.ca/p/meet-crew.html and the SL Enquirer.http://www.slenquirer.com/2015/10/spotlight-on-halloween-mage-dean-lawson.html ==References== {{reflist}} {{Second Life}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arts In Second Life}} [[Category:Second Life]] [[Category:Arts databases]] [[Category:Virtual art museums and galleries]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]]

{{Italic title}} [[File:Escher Circle Limit III.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|''Circle Limit III'', 1959]] '''''Circle Limit III''''' is a [[woodcut]] made in 1959 by Dutch artist [[M. C. Escher]], in which "strings of fish shoot up like rockets from infinitely far away" and then "fall back again whence they came".<ref name="eq">Escher, as quoted by {{harvtxt|Coxeter|1979}}.</ref>
It is one of a series of four woodcuts by Escher depicting ideas from [[hyperbolic geometry]]. Dutch physicist and mathematician Bruno Ernst called it "the best of the four".<ref name="cox79">{{citation|first=H. S. M.|last=Coxeter|authorlink=Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter|title=The non-Euclidean symmetry of Escher's picture 'Circle Limit III'|journal=Leonardo|volume=12|pages=19–25|year=1979|jstor=1574078}}.</ref>
==Inspiration== [[File:Hyperbolic domains 642.png|left|thumb|upright=0.8|The (6,4,2) triangular hyperbolic tiling that inspired Escher]] Escher became interested in [[tessellation|tessellations of the plane]] after a 1936 visit to the [[Alhambra]] in [[Granada]], Spain,<ref name="emmer">{{citation | last = Emmer | first = Michele | doi = 10.1142/S0219887806001594 | issue = 5-6 | journal = International Journal of Geometric Methods in Modern Physics | mr = 2264394 | pages = 869–879 | title = Escher, Coxeter and symmetry | volume = 3 | year = 2006}}.</ref><ref name="mside">{{citation|first=Doris|last=Schattschneider|authorlink=Doris Schattschneider|title=The mathematical side of M. C. Escher|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/201006/rtx100600706p.pdf|journal=Notices of the AMS|volume=57|issue=6|pages=706–718|year=2010}}.</ref> and from the time of his 1937 artwork ''[[Metamorphosis I]]'' he had begun incorporating tessellated human and animal figures into his artworks.<ref name="mside"/>
In a 1958 letter from Escher to [[Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter|H. S. M. Coxeter]], Escher wrote that he was inspired to make his ''Circle Limit'' series by a figure in Coxeter's article "Crystal Symmetry and its Generalizations".<ref name="cox79"/><ref name="emmer"/> Coxeter's figure depicts a [[tessellation]] of the [[hyperbolic plane]] by [[right triangle]]s with angles of 30°, 45°, and 90°; triangles with these angles are possible in hyperbolic geometry but not in Euclidean geometry. This tessellation may be interpreted as depicting the lines of reflection and fundamental domains of the [[Truncated tetrahexagonal tiling|(6,4,2)]] [[triangle group]].<ref>Coxeter expanded on the mathematics of triangle group tessellations, including this one in {{citation | last = Coxeter | first = H. S. M. | authorlink = Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter | doi = 10.4153/CMB-1997-019-0 | issue = 2 | journal = Canadian Mathematical Bulletin | mr = 1451269 | pages = 158–168 | title = The trigonometry of hyperbolic tessellations | volume = 40 | year = 1997}}.</ref> An elementary analysis of Coxeter's figure, as Escher might have understood it, is given by {{harvtxt|Casselman|2010}}.<ref>{{citation|title=How did Escher do it?|first=Bill|last=Casselman|url=http://www.ams.org/samplings/feature-column/fcarc-circle-limit|series=AMS Feature Column|date=June 2010}}.</ref> {{-}}
==Geometry== [[File:Circle limits III with overlay.png|thumb|The [[alternated octagonal tiling]], a [[uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|hyperbolic tiling]] of squares and equilateral triangles, overlaid on Escher's image]] Escher seems to have believed that the white curves of his woodcut, which bisect the fish, represent hyperbolic lines in the [[Poincaré disk model]] of the hyperbolic plane, in which the whole hyperbolic plane is modeled as a disk in the Euclidean plane, and hyperbolic lines are modeled as circular arcs perpendicular to the disk boundary. Indeed, Escher wrote that the fish move "perpendicularly to the boundary".<ref name="eq"/> However, as Coxeter demonstrated, there is no hyperbolic [[arrangement of lines]] whose faces are alternately squares and equilateral triangles, as the figure depicts. Rather, the white curves are [[Hypercycle (geometry)|hypercycles]] that meet the boundary circle at angles of {{nowrap|cos<sup>−1</sup> {{sfrac|2<sup>{{1/4}}</sup> − 2<sup>−{{1/4}}</sup>|2}},}} approximately 80°.<ref name="cox79"/>
The symmetry axes of the triangles and squares that lie between the white lines are true hyperbolic lines. The squares and triangles of the woodcut closely resemble the [[tritetragonal tiling]] of the hyperbolic plane, which also features squares and triangles meeting in the same incidence pattern. However, the precise geometry of these shapes is not the same. In the tritetragonal tiling, the sides of the squares and triangles are hyperbolically straight line segments, which do not link up in smooth curves; instead they form [[polygonal chain]]s with corners. In Escher's woodcut, the sides of the squares and triangles are formed by arcs of hypercycles, which are not straight in hyperbolic geometry, but which connect smoothly to each other without corners.
The points at the centers of the squares, where four fish meet at their fins, form the vertices of an [[order-8 triangular tiling]], while the points where three fish fins meet and the points where three white lines cross together form the vertices of its [[Dual polyhedron|dual]], the [[octagonal tiling]].<ref name="cox79"/> Similar tessellations by lines of fish may be constructed for other hyperbolic tilings formed by [[polygon]]s other than triangles and squares, or with more than three white curves at each crossing.<ref>{{citation|first=Douglas|last=Dunham|contribution=More “Circle Limit III” patterns|url=https://www.d.umn.edu/~ddunham/dunbrid06.pdf|title=The Bridges Conference: Mathematical Connections in Art, Music, and Science, London, 2006}}.</ref>
Euclidean coordinates of circles containing the three most prominent white curves in the woodcut may be obtained by calculations in the field of rational numbers extended by the square roots of two and three.<ref>{{citation|first=H. S. M.|last=Coxeter|authorlink=Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter|contribution=The trigonometry of Escher’s woodcut ''Circle Limit III''|title=M.C.Escher’s Legacy: A Centennial Celebration|year=2003|publisher=Springer|pages=297–304|doi=10.1007/3-540-28849-X_29}}.</ref>
==Symmetry== Viewed as a pattern, ignoring the colors of the fish, in the hyperbolic plane, the woodcut has three-fold and four-fold [[rotational symmetry]] at the centers of its triangles and squares, respectively, and order-three [[dihedral symmetry]] (the symmetry of an equilateral triangle) at the points where the white curves cross. In [[John Horton Conway|John Conway]]'s [[orbifold notation]], this set of symmetries is denoted 433. Each fish provides a fundamental region for this symmetry group. Contrary to appearances, the fish do not have [[bilateral symmetry]]: the white curves of the drawing are not axes of reflection symmetry.<ref>{{citation | last = Conway | first = J. H. | authorlink = John Horton Conway | contribution = The orbifold notation for surface groups | doi = 10.1017/CBO9780511629259.038 | location = Cambridge | mr = 1200280 | pages = 438–447 | publisher = Cambridge Univ. Press | series = London Math. Soc. Lecture Note Ser. | title = Groups, Combinatorics & Geometry (Durham, 1990) | volume = 165 | year = 1992}}. Conway wrote that "The work ''Circle Limit III'' is equally intriguing" (in comparison to ''Circle Limit IV'', which has a different symmetry group), and uses is it as an example of this symmetry group.</ref><ref>{{citation|first=Peter|last=Herford|title=The geometry of M. C. Escher's circle-Limit-Woodcuts|journal=Zentralblatt für Didaktik der Mathematik|year=1999|volume=31|issue=5|pages=144–148|doi=10.1007/BF02659805}}. Paper presented to the 8th International Conference on Geometry, Nahsholim (Israel), March 7–14, 1999.</ref> For example, the angle at the back of the right fin is 90° (where four fins meet), but at the back of the much smaller left fin it is 120° (where three fins meet).
==Printing details== The fish in ''Circle Limit III'' are depicted in four colors, allowing each string of fish to have a single color and each two adjacent fish to have different colors. Together with the black ink used to outline the fish, the overall woodcut has five colors. It is printed from five wood blocks, each of which provides one of the colors within a quarter of the disk, for a total of 20 impressions. The diameter of the outer circle, as printed, is {{cvt|41.5|cm|frac=8}}.<ref>{{citation|title=M. C. Escher: The Graphic Work|page=10|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lq-EZiRdPswC&pg=PR1|publisher=Taschen|year=2001|first=M. C.|last=Escher}}.</ref>
==Exhibits== As well as being included in the collection of the [[Escher Museum]] in [[The Hague]], there is a copy of ''Circle Limit III'' in the collection of the [[National Gallery of Canada]].<ref>[http://www.gallery.ca/en/see/collections/artwork.php?mkey=80 ''Circle Limit III''], [[National Gallery of Canada]], retrieved 2013-07-09.</ref>

[[File:Circular reporting.svg|thumb|300px|Two basic ways that circular reporting can happen. Dashed lines indicate sourcing that isn't visible to the final reviewer. In both cases, one original source (top) appears to the final reviewer (bottom) as two independent sources]] '''Circular reporting''' or '''false confirmation''' is a situation in [[source criticism]] where a piece of information appears to come from multiple independent sources, but in reality comes from only one source.{{cite web|url=http://www.army.forces.gc.ca/caj/documents/vol_11/iss_2/CAJ_Vol11.2_12_e.pdf|title=The Challenge of Centralized Control Faced by the Intelligence Function in Afghanistan|publisher=Canadian Army Journal|date=Summer 2008|author1=Marcus Sterzer, CD|author2=Patrick McDuff B.A.|author3=Jacek Flasz|lastauthoramp=yes|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305201954/http://www.army.forces.gc.ca/caj/documents/vol_11/iss_2/CAJ_Vol11.2_12_e.pdf|archivedate=2012-03-05|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/mojoblog/archives/2008/06/8595_three_days_in_r.html|title=The Cocktail Napkin Plan for Regime Change in Iran|date=June 2008|publisher=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]}} In many cases, the problem happens mistakenly through sloppy intelligence gathering practices. However, at other times the situation can be intentionally contrived by the original source as a way of reinforcing the widespread belief in its information.{{cite book|title=I Solemnly Swear|author1=Micheal T. Hurley |author2=Kenton V. Smith |ISBN=0-595-29947-4|chapter=8|page=128|quote=Circular reporting occurs when what is reported is fed back to the originator in revised fashion which makes it difficult to objectively view the end product until you can trace back the sources to determine where the original information actually came from. Pan Am would eventually try to play that game by trying to introduce into court news reports that they themselves had a hand in producing.}} [https://books.google.com/books?q=%22Circular+reporting+occurs+when+what+is+reported+is+fed+back+to+the+originator+in+revised+fashion+which+makes+it+difficult+to+objectively+view+the+end+product+until+you+can+trace+back+the+sources+to+determine+where+the+original+information+actually+came+from.+Pan+Am+would+eventually+try+to+play+that+game+by+trying+to+introduce+into+court+news+reports+that+they+themselves+had+a+hand+in+producing.%22&btnG=Search+Books Google Book search], retrieved on 23 July 2009. This problem occurs in a variety of fields, including [[intelligence (information gathering)|intelligence gathering]], [[media echo chamber|journalism]], and scholarly [[research]]. It is of particular concern in [[military intelligence]] because the original source has a higher likelihood of wanting to pass on misinformation, and because the chain of reporting is [[fog of war|more prone to being obscured]]. The case of the 2002 [[Niger uranium forgeries]] was a classic instance of circular reporting by intelligence agencies.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/feb/17/nation/na-niger17|title=2006-02-17|publisher=Los Angeles Times|quote="This became a classic case of circular reporting," said a U.S. intelligence official who spoke on condition of anonymity because he is not authorized to talk to reporters. "It seemed like we were hearing it from lots of places. People didn't realize it was the same bad information coming in different doors." | first1=Bob | last1=Drogin | first2=Tom | last2=Hamburger | date=2006-02-17}} ==Examples involving Wikipedia== [[File:Relationship between Wikipedia and the press.svg|thumb|Diagram illustrating circular reporting by Wikipedia and the press]] [[Wikipedia]] is sometimes criticized for being used as a source of circular reporting.{{cite web |url=https://arstechnica.com/media/news/2009/05/wikipedia-hoax-reveals-limits-of-journalists-research.ars |title=Wikipedia hoax points to the limits of journalists' research |publisher=Ars Technica |last=Timmer |first=John |date=May 2009 }} Wikipedia advises researchers and journalists to [[WP:Citing Wikipedia|be wary of, and generally avoid, using Wikipedia as a direct source]], and instead focus on verifiable information found in an article's [[WP:Citing sources|cited references]]. In the following examples, false claims were propagated on Wikipedia and in news sources because of circular reporting. [[Randall Munroe|Randall Monroe]], in his comic [[xkcd]], coined the term "citogenesis" to describe this phenomenon.{{Cite web|url=https://xkcd.com/978/|title=xkcd: Citogenesis|website=xkcd.com|access-date=2018-09-20}} *Wikipedia and [[The Northern Echo]]: In January 2014 a statement was anonymously added to the Wikipedia page on UK comedian/broadcaster [[Dave Gorman]] stating that "he had taken a career break for a sponsored hitch-hike around the Pacific Rim countries". When this was questioned, an article published at a later date (September 2014) in ''The Northern Echo'', a daily regional newspaper in North East England was cited as evidence. The falsity of the original claim was confirmed by Gorman in an episode of his UK TV show [[Modern Life is Goodish]] (first broadcast 22 November 2016).{{cite news|last1=Hardwick|first1=Viv|title=Mears sets his sights on UK|url=http://wayback.archive.org/web/20140929214806/http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/entertainment/11460855.Mears_sets_his_sights_on_UK/|accessdate=30 August 2017|work=[[The Northern Echo]]|date=9 September 2014|quote=He once hitchhiked around the Pacific Rim countries}} * Wikipedia and ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' in 2009, regarding [[Karl-Theodor Freiherr von und zu Guttenberg]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bildblog.de/5704/|publisher=BildBlog.de|title=Wie ich Freiherr von Guttenberg zu Wilhelm machte|language=German|date=2009-02-10}}
{{cite web|url=http://tech.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=09/02/10/2211220|title=False Fact On Wikipedia Proves Itself|publisher=[[Slashdot]]|date=2009-02-11}} * Wikipedia and ''[[The Independent]]'' in 2007, propagating the false information that [[Sacha Baron Cohen]] worked at Goldman Sachs.{{cite web|url=http://techdebug.com/blog/2008/04/19/wikipedia-article-creates-circular-references/|title=Wikipedia Article creates Circular references|publisher=Tech Debug blog|date=2009-01-14}} * Wikipedia on the [[coati]] beginning in 2008, when an arbitrary addition "also known as....the Brazilian aardvark" by an American student resulted in much subsequent citation and usage of the unsubstantiated nickname as part of the general consensus, including published articles in ''[[The Independent]]'', ''[[The Daily Mail]]'', and a book published by the [[University of Chicago]].{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/elements/2014/05/how-a-raccoon-became-an-aardvark.html|title=How a Raccoon Became an Aardvark|publisher=New Yorker|date=2014-05-19}} ==See also== {{external media | width = 210px | float = right | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cSKGa_7XJkg How false news can spread - Noah Tavlin], [[TED (conference)|TED-ED]]{{cite web | title =How false news can spread - Noah Tavlin | work = | publisher =[[TED (conference)|TED-ED]] | date =August 27, 2015 | url =http://ed.ted.com/lessons/how-false-news-can-spread-noah-tavlin | accessdate =August 29, 2015 }} }} * [[Media echo chamber]] * [[Circular reference]] * [[Ghost word]] * [[Hoax]] * [[Rumor]] * [[Woozle effect]] * [[Reliability of Wikipedia]] * [[Wikipedia:List of citogenesis incidents]] * [[Circular reasoning]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Disinformation}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Circular reporting}} [[Category:Causal fallacies]] [[Category:Communication of falsehoods]] [[Category:Criticism of journalism]] [[Category:Literary criticism]] [[Category:Philosophical logic]] [[Category:Fake news]]

'''Dacian art''' is the art associated with the peoples known as [[Dacians]] or North Thracians; The Dacians created an art style in which the influences of Scythians and the Greeks can be seen. They were highly skilled in gold and silver working and in pottery making. Pottery was white with red decorations in floral, geometric, and stylized animal motifs. Similar decorations were worked in metal, especially the figure of a horse, which was common on Dacian coins.{{sfn| Waldman| Mason |2006|p=208}} ==Background == [[File:Daci Terra Getarum cf Strabo.JPG|thumb|200px|right|Dacians regions cf. [[Strabo]] (ca. 20 AD) by Muller (1877) {{sfn|Müller|1877|loc=tabulae XV}}]] [[File:Muzeuldeistorienaturalavienaaurdacic2.JPG|thumb|200px|right|Dacian gold bowl found in Transylvania (Vienna Museum)]] The Geto-Dacians lived in a very large territory, stretching from the [[Balkans]] to the northern [[Carpathians]] and from the [[Black Sea]] and the river [[Tyras]] to the [[Tisza|Tisa]] plain, sometimes even to the [[Middle Danube]].{{sfn|MacKenzie|1986|p=25}} Between 15th-12th century, the Dacian-Getae culture was influenced by the Bronze Age Tumulus-Urnfield warriors.{{sfn|Mountain|1998|p=59}} Dacian civilization went through several stages of development, from the Thracian stage in the Bronze Age to the classical period of the Geto-Dacians (the first century BC to the first century AD).{{sfn|Giurescu|Nestorescu|1981|p=47}} In the [[Bronze Age]], proto-Thracian populations emerged from the fusion of the local [[Eneolithic|Eneolithic (Chalcolithic)]] stock with the intruders of the transitional [[Indo-Europeanization Period]]. From these proto-Thracians, in the [[Iron Age]], there were developed the Dacians of the [[Danubian-Carpathian Area]] on the one hand and the Thracians of the eastern [[Balkan Peninsula]] on the other.{{sfn|Dumitrescu|Boardman|1982|p=53}} ==Pre-Dacian periods== North Thracian population was chiefly an Early Bronze Age mix of the descendants of intrusive stockbreeding people and of survivors of the autochthonous Chalcolithic culture that the newcomers had destroyed. In this ethnic synthesis which gave birth to the Thracian people, the former predominated but, especially in the more mountainous areas, vestiges of Chalcolithic traditions survived through the Early and into the Middle Bronze Age.{{sfn|Hoddinott|1989|p=52}} The local, Daco-Thracian art should not be mistaken for the art of the Thracians south of the Balkans although mutual influences had undoubtedly appeared.{{sfn|Popescu|1971|p=62}} Thracian art was typically geometric in its decoration, a taste which was a remnant of Late Bronze Age traditions.{{sfn|Farkas|1981|p=37}} While the Thracian tribes adopted-no doubt from the Scythians-some aspects of mounted nomadism in the first millennium B.C., they also preserved many traditions of the European Bronze Age and belonged more to the world of European cultures than to that of the East.{{sfn|Farkas|1981|p=33}} ==Classical Dacian periods== The 1st century BC silver work from the lower Danube region consists mostly of bracelets and fibulae alongside of a small number of decorative disks, plaques, and bowls. To distinguish it from earlier Thracian silver work, one might label this later silver work as Geto-Dacian or Geto-Thracian depending on whether is found above or below the lower Danube.{{sfn|Olmsted|2001|p=22}} The design of Geto-Dacian helmets (i.e. Ciumesti, Iron Gate) is sufficiently unusual in ancient art to offer the opportunity to trace it to its origin, and, thereby, provide some insight into the Scythian elements that went into the formation of early Dacian art and the means by which ancient Oriental motifs survived and were transmitted into Europe{{sfn|Goldman|1970|p=904}} Almost identical in decoration and details of craftsmanship are the two silver beakers, now in Bucharest and New York and unquestionably were made in the same metalsmith shop as the helmet.{{sfn|Goldman|1970|p=904}} ==Gallery== File:00Tezaur MNIR IMG 6195.JPG File:00Tezaur MNIR IMG 6194.JPG File:00Tezaur MNIR IMG 6196.JPG File:00TezaurMNIRIMG 6042.JPG File:00MINIRDACIAN SILVERIMG 6120.JPG File:Coif getic tezaurul de la Peretu detaliu MNIR.jpg File:Peretu Helmet side view Muzeul National de Istorie al Romaniei.jpg File:Helmet_of_Cotofenesti_at_the_National_Museum_of_Romanian_History_2011_-_Mythological_Scene_on_the_Back.jpg File:Helmet_of_Cotofenesti_at_the_National_Museum_of_Romanian_History_2011_-_Front_View.jpg File:Dacian_Gold_Bracelet_at_the_National_Museum_of_Romanian_History_2011_-_2.jpg File:TezaurulRomanieiMNIRGeticHelmet.JPG File:ThumbMNIR Tezaur 1112.JPG File:ThumbMNIRGoldArtefacts.JPG File:ThumbMNIRTEZAUR.JPG File:Dacian fibulae Cluj Musem 1st century BC.jpg File:Dacian Silver Fibulae.jpg File:Dacian silver.jpg File:Dacian shiels.jpg File:2007 07260190.jpg File:Classical type of Dacian-Hallstattian gold bracelet.jpg File:Dacian Silver clasp Posaga.JPG File:Sword hilt Dacia (Covoru, Brasov).jpg File:Helmet and standard.JPG File:Dacian shield and helmets.JPG == Notes == {{reflist|3}} == References ==

{{Cleanup|reason=article needs additional citations|date=September 2013}} {{infobox organization | image = Det Danske Filminstitut logo.gif | caption = Logo of the Danish Film Institute, since 1999. | motto = | formation = 1972 | extinction = | type = | headquarters = [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] | leader_title = Chief Executive | leader_name = [[Claus Ladegaard]] | name = Danish Film Institute | size = | abbreviation = DFI | website = {{url|dfi.dk/Service/English.aspx}} }} The '''Danish Film Institute''' ({{lang-da|Det Danske Filminstitut}}) is the national [[Denmark|Danish]] agency responsible for supporting and encouraging film and cinema culture, and for conserving these in the national interest.
Also known as '''''Filmhuset''''' ("the film house"), it is located in [[Gothersgade]] in central [[Copenhagen]]. Facilities directed at the general public include a library and [[Cinemateket]] which is Denmark's national film museum.
It is an institution under the [[Ministry of Culture of Denmark|Danish Ministry of Cultural Affairs]]. The current Director of the Film Institute is Claus Ladegaard.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.b.dk/kultur/claus-ladegaard-tager-styringen-hos-filminstituttet|title=Claus Ladegaard tager styringen hos Filminstituttet|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Berlingske|accessdate=2018-02-27}}</ref> The institute is a member of [[European Film Promotion]], the network of European film organisations for the worldwide promotion of European film.
==History== The Danish Film Institute was founded in 1972, replacing the Danish Film Foundation (Danish: Den Danske Filmfond). In 1996 a new Danish Film Act merged the Film Institute with Statens Filmcentral and the National Danish Film Museum with effect from the following year and at the same event the institution relocated to its current premises at Filmhuset in Gothersgade.
==Activities== The Danish Film Institute is active within three main areas which are subsidized: * Production and development of all types of films * Distribution and communication of films and film culture * Archives and museum activities The Film Institute presents Danish films at feastivals abroad and in Denmark and subsidizes the import of foreign quality films. It maintains the [[Danish National Filmography]] (''Danmarks Nationalfilmografi''), a database about Danish films since 1896.
==Facilities==
===Cinemateket=== Cinemateket is the national Danish film museum, dedicated to broaden the knowledge and interest in Danish as well as foreign film. It has three cinemas which show a combination of film classics and quality films of various themes. Occasionally contemporary films which would otherwise not reach the Danish market are shown. In the videoteque in the library is it possible to watch [[short film|short]] and [[documentary film]]s. Other facilities include a book shop, a café and a restaurant.
===Library=== The Danish Film Institute's library on the first floor holds 55,000 books and subscribes to 240 mainly European and American magazines. The library lends regular books—usually for a period of one month—while magazines, manuscripts and rarer publications may only be referenced on the premises.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aok.dk/byen-rundt/det-danske-filminstituts-bibliotek|title=Det Danske Filminstituts Bibliotek|publisher=AOK|accessdate=2010-04-10}}</ref>
